Award.AwardTitle: Three dimensional deep wavelet scattering for quantum energy interpolation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Physical quantities are often computed as solutions to a system of complex mathematical equations, which may require huge computations for intricate physical states. Quantum chemistry calculations of molecular energies is such an example. Indeed, computing the energy of a molecule, given the charges and positions of its nuclei, is a central issue in computational chemistry with important applications in molecular dynamics, materials science, and drug discovery. Machine learning algorithms do not simulate the physical system but estimate solutions by learning from a training set of known examples. However, such learning algorithms may require a number of examples that is exponential in the system dimension, and are thus intractable; this phenomena is referred to as the "curse of dimensionality." This proposal will develop a novel approach for the estimation of molecular energies based on the "scattering transform." The scattering transform estimates molecular energies, and circumvents the curse of dimensionality, by utilizing a multiscale, multilevel architecture that takes advantage of physical invariants. The resulting algorithms have the potential to significantly speed up the computation of highly accurate molecular energy estimates, leading to large scale atomistic simulations with greatly improved accuracy, speed, and adaptability, thus shifting the paradigm of multiscale modeling. The PI will additionally mentor an undergraduate student and train a graduate student in this field, thus setting up the potential for dissemination of the core ideas to a broader audience.

The scattering transform has the structure of a deep convolutional network, but is composed of iterated wavelet transforms and complex modulus operators. Such networks have been used in computer vision for the analysis and classification of two dimensional images and audio tasks involving one dimensional signals. A multiscale three dimensional scattering transform network is novel both in practice (multiscale 3D) and design (for quantum chemistry), and has the chance to influence these types of architectures moving forward. A systematic approach will attack the primary object on several fronts: (1) development of efficient 3D filters with the appropriate symmetry and stability properties; (2) rigorous error analysis of the scattering regression algorithm for various components of the molecular energy functional; (3) deeper understanding of the scattering network via provable relations with fast multipole methods. The methods used to carry out these objectives will include: (i) wavelet filter design and efficient signal processing algorithms; (ii) utilization of Littlewood-Paley Theory in conjunction with polynomial (Taylor) approximation theory; (iii) multiscale analysis; (iv) numerical experiments to validate methods. By rigorously linking deep learning architectures with physical chemistry, the research in this proposal will take place at the interface of data science and scientific computation, for the mutual gain of both.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The design of new molecules (e.g., for drugs) and materials (e.g., for batteries) in many cases requires computing properties of the associated atomic system at the quantum scale. Such computations, which are carried out on computers, are often extremely expensive, pushing the limits of even the most powerful computing resources. This computational bottleneck inhibits research in the chemical and materials sciences, which in turn slows the pace at which new products can be introduced to the public at large. 

Machine learning algorithms use existing, already computed data, to learn patterns and interpolate (or sometimes even extrapolate) quantities of interest to new molecules or materials. In this project we developed new machine learning algorithms for estimating the ground state energy of atomic systems associated to molecules and materials. The ground state energy is required to infer numerous other properties of molecules and materials, and its computation is the focus of a large body of research in quantum chemistry.

The design of such machine learning algorithms, though, is not simple, and requires specialized considerations specific to chemistry and materials science. For such machine learning algorithms to make accurate predictions, they must respect the underlying physical and chemical properties of the representative atomic system. In this project we developed a new class of machine learning algorithms based upon a representation of the atomic system called the three-dimensional wavelet scattering transform. Wavelet scattering representations of atomic systems possess the required physical invariances, stability guarantees, and scaling properties with respect to the ground state energy. Wavelet scattering machine learned models developed in this project were able to accurately predict the ground state energy of small, drug-like molecules in addition to the ground state energies of atomic systems of interest for the development of new lithium-ion batteries, but at a fraction of the computational cost required for a direct quantum mechanical calculation.

Several graduate students were partially supported as part of this project. Additionally, two undergraduate students participated in the project through a joint initiative with a separately funded summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program. Finally, during the project duration the PI was able to develop a new graduate course on applied and computational harmonic analysis that covered many of the fundamental mathematical topics at the heart of the wavelet scattering transform.
